items.title: Saving PDF documents with a char ':' in filename
items.body:
### **What did you do?**
I needed to save an list of PIL Images to one pdf file. So I wrote code like this:
```Python3
    img = image_list[0]
    img.save(get_file_name(FILE_PATH) + "_stamped_" + get_time() + ".pdf",
                                 resolution = 100.0,
                                 save_all=True,
                                 append_images=image_list[1:])
```
And get_time func:
```Python3 
def get_time():
    # Returns smth. like this: "12:00" or "02:51"
    return str(str(datetime.datetime.now().time())[0:5])
```
### **What happend**
But when I ran the program, the pdf file was created, but it had an incomplete name and size of 0 bytes

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64750224/90128432-8888da80-dd6f-11ea-8935-4eec78c2735e.png)

The problem was that Windows does not support ':' in file names and Python cannot to  create the file. But PIL does not give an error because of this and simply terminates the program. If the function is changed in this way
` return str(str(datetime.datetime.now().time())[0:5]).replace(":", "-")` , then everything will work.

### **What did you expect to happen?**
PIL Image.save raise Exception

P.S.

items.title: _imaging.py doesn't have PILLOW_VERSION attribute after building with all dependencies with VS2019
items.body:
<!--
Thank you for reporting an issue.

Follow these guidelines to ensure your issue is handled properly.

If you have a ...

1.  General question: consider asking the question on Stack Overflow
    with the python-imaging-library tag:

    * https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/python-imaging-library

    Do not ask a question in both places.

    If you think you have found a bug or have an unexplained exception
    then file a bug report here.

2.  Bug report: include a self-contained, copy-pastable example that
    generates the issue if possible. Be concise with code posted.
    Guidelines on how to provide a good bug report:

    * https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve

    Bug reports which follow these guidelines are easier to diagnose,
    and are often handled much more quickly.

3.  Feature request: do a quick search of existing issues
    to make sure this has not been asked before.

We know asking good questions takes effort, and we appreciate your time.
Thank you.
-->

### What did you do?
Built pillow from source using the script in winbuild. 

### What did you expect to happen?

I expected the package to work.

### What actually happened?

Package seems broken.

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: Windows 10
* Python: 3.7.7
* Pillow: 7.2.0

<!--
Please include **code** that reproduces the issue and whenever possible, an **image** that demonstrates the issue. Please upload images to GitHub, not to third-party file hosting sites. If necessary, add the image to a zip or tar archive.

The best reproductions are self-contained scripts with minimal dependencies. If you are using a framework such as Plone, Django, or Buildout, try to replicate the issue just using Pillow.
-->

1. Extract pillow-7.2.0.tar.gz
2. cd to winbuild
3. python build_prepare.py
4. cd to build
5. build_dep_all  (had to modify `winbuild\build\lcms2-2.11\Projects\VC2017\lcms2_static\lcms2_static.vcxproj` to point to the installed windows SDK version (10.0.19041.0) for it to compile, but otherwise, everything worked fine).
6. build_pillow
7. back in the root of the extracted package, run `python setup.py install`
*   shows the [following output](https://pastebin.pl/view/ed23290b)
8. python selftest.py
Fails with 

```
RuntimeWarning: The _imaging extension was built for another version of Pillow or PIL:
Core version: None
Pillow version: 7.2.0
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "selftest.py", line 6, in <module>
    from PIL import Image, features
  File "c:\venv\lib\site-packages\pillow-7.2.0-py3.7-win-amd64.egg\PIL\Image.py", line 100, in <module>
ImportError: The _imaging extension was built for another version of Pillow or PIL:
Core version: None
Pillow version: 7.2.0
```

Because `PIL\_imaging.py` loads from `_imaging.cp37-win_amd64.pyd` with no attribute named `PILLOW_VERSION`.

items.title: How to make a clear JPEG thumbnail
items.body:
### What did you do?
```python
Image.open('unsplash.jpeg')  ## https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1522521976874-e5d7c6b90db3
Image.thumbnail(size = (1500, 2250))
Image.save('unsplash_t.jpeg', 'JPEG', quality=70, filter="antialias")
```

### What did you expect to happen?
thumbnail it like this: https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1522521976874-e5d7c6b90db3?w=1500&q=55 (a clear plane with 133k)
### What actually happened?
I got this picture (some artifacts around the plane with 131k): 
![photo-1522521976874-e5d7c6b90db3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16457655/89443959-993fbc00-d783-11ea-9444-0746edd90055.jpeg)
### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: Centos 8
* Python: 3.8
* Pillow: 7.0

Some infomations:
https://graphicdesign.stackexchange.com/questions/51933/how-does-this-image-interleave-from-grayscale-to-color
https://cloudinary.com/blog/progressive_jpegs_and_green_martians

items.title: Unrecognized Tiff from srtm
items.body:
Get data from srtm: http://srtm.csi.cgiar.org/wp-content/uploads/files/srtm_5x5/TIFF/srtm_64_03.zip
Try open tif by pillow and code is crash:
```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-

import sys
import os
import numpy
from PIL import Image

image = Image.open(sys.argv[1])
print(image)
image.rotate(45).show()
image.save('1.png', 'png')
image.show()
```
I can not show, save, rotate, transform to numpy.array.

```
<PIL.TiffImagePlugin.TiffImageFile image mode=I;16S size=6000x6000 at 0x7F500FD68978>
Traceback (most recent call last):
```

items.title: cannot identify image file %r" % (filename if filename else fp) PIL.UnidentifiedImageError: cannot identify image file <_io.BufferedReader name='SourceData/anime-faces/aqua_eyes/._danbooru_2559693_dc628b766d7142f2d2d9c75559e36eb5.jpg'>
items.body:
I use the ImageFolder and DataLoader from torch and torch vision to open the images in dataset. It just cannot read **some** images and throw this error. (These images are not broken.)

I found it is strange that the actual image name is **danbooru_2559693_dc628b766d7142f2d2d9c75559e36eb5.jpg**, while the error (shown in the title) indicates that as **._danbooru_2559693_dc628b766d7142f2d2d9c75559e36eb5.jpg**. Where does the **._** come from?


Here is the code:
```python
dataset=torchvision.datasets.ImageFolder(opt.data_path, transform=transform)
dataloader=torch.utils.data.DataLoader(dataset,
                                           batch_size=opt.batch_size,
                                           shuffle=True,
                                           num_workers=opt.num_workers,
                                           drop_last=True
                                           )
```
ps: opt.data_path is "SourceData/anime-faces/" Under the anime-faces directory, there are lots of subdirectories containing different images.

items.title: PSD Plugin does not register a MIME type
items.body:
The [`PSDImagePlugin`](https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/blob/master/src/PIL/PsdImagePlugin.py) does not register a MIME type as I'd expect it to. The correct MIME for PSD images, according to IANA, is ["image/vnd.adobe.photoshop"](https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/image/vnd.adobe.photoshop).

Is there a reason this isn't registered?

items.title: Docs: nitpicky warnings
items.body:
After merging #4739, #4771, #4773, #4774, there are still 18 nitpicky warnings (down from 400!) that I don't know how to fix:

```
C:\Git\Pillow\docs\handbook\image-file-formats.rst:186: WARNING: py:attr reference target not found: PIL.Image.Image.tile
C:\Git\Pillow\docs\handbook\image-file-formats.rst:711: WARNING: py:meth reference target not found: PIL.Image.Image.convert2byte

C:\Git\Pillow\docs\handbook\image-file-formats.rst:775: WARNING: py:attr reference target not found: PIL.Image.Image.tag_v2
C:\Git\Pillow\docs\handbook\image-file-formats.rst:784: WARNING: py:attr reference target not found: PIL.Image.Image.tag
C:\Git\Pillow\docs\handbook\image-file-formats.rst:823: WARNING: py:attr reference target not found: PIL.TiffImagePlugin.ImageFileDirectory_v2.tagtype
C:\Git\Pillow\docs\handbook\image-file-formats.rst:851: WARNING: py:attr reference target not found: PIL.TiffImagePlugin.ImageFileDirectory_v2.tagtype
C:\Git\Pillow\docs\handbook\writing-your-own-file-decoder.rst:29: WARNING: py:meth reference target not found: _open
C:\Git\Pillow\docs\handbook\writing-your-own-file-decoder.rst:29: WARNING: py:attr reference target not found: tile
C:\Git\Pillow\docs\handbook\writing-your-own-file-decoder.rst:39: WARNING: py:meth reference target not found: _open
C:\Git\Pillow\docs\handbook\writing-your-own-file-decoder.rst:106: WARNING: py:attr reference target not found: tile
C:\Git\Pillow\docs\handbook\writing-your-own-file-decoder.rst:109: WARNING: py:attr reference target not found: tile
C:\Git\Pillow\docs\handbook\writing-your-own-file-decoder.rst:137: WARNING: py:attr reference target not found: tile
C:\Git\Pillow\docs\reference\ImageMath.rst:63: WARNING: py:func reference target not found: PIL.ImageMath.convert
C:\Git\Pillow\docs\reference\ImageMath.rst:63: WARNING: py:func reference target not found: PIL.ImageMath.float
C:\Git\Pillow\docs\reference\ImageMath.rst:63: WARNING: py:func reference target not found: PIL.ImageMath.int
c:\git\pillow\src\PIL\ImageWin.py:docstring of PIL.ImageWin.Dib.expose:3: WARNING: py:meth reference target not found: CDC.GetHandleAttrib
C:\Git\Pillow\docs\releasenotes\4.2.0.rst:28: WARNING: py:data reference target not found: PIL.Image.MAX_IMAGE_PIXELS
```

The `ImageMath` references are especially tricky, because unless they are marked as `.. py:currentmodule:: None`, their names will have a prefix, but with the directive, they clash with the standard library.

~The `MAX_PIXELS` reference appears to be a typo for~ `MAX_IMAGE_PIXELS` which is just omitted, but I can't come up with a good description for it. I'm also not sure where to put it.

These are ignored with `nitpick_ignore` in #4776 for now to allow CI builds to pass. Remove it to check again.

items.title: Processing big images
items.body:
Hi guys,

I'm a newbie with Pillow, but I have giant problem to solve. I have approximately 8milions of images (JPG, TIFF, and some different RAW types) to process (almost 200TiB of files) and transform in "tiles" (I'm using Deepzoom, that use Pillow to do the magic).

In my tests it was everything OK until I found a bigger image with almost 200mpixels, when the system crashed with this exception:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
[...]
  File "/home/wbraga/Git/dzi-tools/.nox/teste_mosaico/lib/python3.8/site-packages/PIL/Image.py", line 2868, in _open_core
    _decompression_bomb_check(im.size)
  File "/home/wbraga/Git/dzi-tools/.nox/teste_mosaico/lib/python3.8/site-packages/PIL/Image.py", line 2791, in _decompression_bomb_check
    raise DecompressionBombError(
PIL.Image.DecompressionBombError: Image size (199968786 pixels) exceeds limit of 178956970 pixels, could be decompression bomb DOS attack.
```

After view some code I arrived to the line 84 on site-packages/PIL/Image.py, with this formule:

`MAX_IMAGE_PIXELS` = int(1024 * 1024 * 1024 // 4 // 3)

where I changed to:

`MAX_IMAGE_PIXELS = int(1024 * 1024 * 1024 * 2 // 4 // 3)`

... and after that my code ran. Not fine, yet, but ran. The image was processed but I'm receiving this warning bellow:

```
 /home/wbraga/Git/dzi-tools/.nox/teste_mosaico/lib/python3.8/site-packages/Pillow-7.1.2-py3.8-linux-x86_64.egg/PIL/Image.py:2797: DecompressionBombWarning: Image size (199968786 pixels) exceeds limit of 178956970 pixels, could be decompression bomb DOS attack.
  warnings.warn(
```

My doubt is: Is there a more easy way to change this (a variable, atribute, function...) or in fact it is hardcoded?

Thanks for an help or suggest.


* OS: Ubuntu Linux 20.04 / Ubuntu Linux 16.04 
* Python: 3.8.2  / 3.8.3
* Pillow: 7.2.0 / 7.0.0

items.title: Wheel support for linux aarch64

labels.name: Installation
labels.description: Usually a problem with …

items.body:
**Summary**
Installing pillow on aarch64 via pip using command "pip3 install pillow" tries to build wheel from source code

**Problem description**
pillow don't have wheel for aarch64 on PyPI repository. So, while installing pillow via pip on aarch64, pip builds wheel for same resulting in it takes more time to install pillow. Making wheel available for aarch64 will benefit aarch64 users by minimizing pillow installation time.

**Expected Output**
Pip should be able to download pillow wheel from PyPI repository rather than building it from source code.

@pillow-team, please let me know if I can help you building wheel/uploading to PyPI repository. I am curious to make pillow wheel available for aarch64. It will be a great opportunity for me to work with you.

items.title: Proposition of code refactoring
items.body:
Hello, everyone.

I've been using Pillow for some parts of my PhD thesis, and it's been very useful for me. Because of this, I would like to find a way to contribute to make it even better, if I can.

My initial idea was to check the code base to find possible missing features I could implement. Nevertheless, I had some problem to do this, because I found the code was a little too difficult to read (for newcomers, at least). In my opinion, some part of this difficult is related too:

1. The package PIL has a lot of modules, it's not divided in subpackages.
2. Some modules are too long. For example, the module `Image.py` has more than 3000 lines, and the `Image` class alone has more than 2000 lines.
3. Many methods and functions are missing docstrings, or don't have names that make them easy to understand.
4. The "Pythonic" style isn't always used.

Would you be interested to make some refactoring on the code? If you like this idea, I could come up with some propositions for the reorganization of the module `Image.py`, for example, and we could discuss. After we agree on something, I would be happy to work on this topic.

Looking forward to cooperate with you!

items.title: CalledProcessError saving icns file to io.BytesIO()

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Any unexpected behavior, until confirmed feature.

items.body:
Currently, writing an icns file to an io.ByteIO object fails. This operation is supported by other filetypes (jpg, png, ico, etc) so I'm not clear if this report falls under feature request or bug

### What did you do?
Write icns file to io.BytesIO() object
```python
from PIL import Image
import io
import base64

im = Image.new(mode="RGBA", size=(256,256), color=(0,100,246,255))
f = io.BytesIO()
im.save(fp=f, format="icns")

b64 = base64.b64encode(f.getvalue()).decode()
print(f'Image: {b64}')
```

### What did you expect to happen?
Fill the io.BytesIO object 

### What actually happened?
macOS's iconutil failed because it was provided an empty filename for output (-o)
```bash
subprocess.CalledProcessError: Command '['iconutil', '-c', 'icns', '-o', '', '/var/folders/91/q75bkgks1196cr1rsr0399540000gn/T/tmppmsm3z2y.iconset']' returned non-zero exit status 1.
```

I believe one solution would be if `filename` variable is empty then use a dummy name and after popen returns, read the file from disk.

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: macOS Mojave 10.14.6
* Python: 3.7.7
* Pillow: 7.1.2

### What did you do?
I am trying to improve image contrast.

### What did you expect to happen?
I expect to be able to control the cutoff values for each side of the histograms. 

### What actually happened?
The cutoff value of PIL.ImageOps.autocontrast() cutoff the histogram from both side. What should happen is the user should be given the custom control to specify the percentage cutoff of both the right and the left side separately
### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: Windows 10
* Python: Python 3.8.2 
* Pillow: PIL 7.1.2

```python
from PIL import Image, ImageOps

img = Image.open("ky.jpg").convert("L")

edited.save("pil_1.jpg")
```

items.title: Line width is broken for super long lines
items.body:
Code for two images with diagonal lines differing only in coordinates of the points: 

```python
from PIL import Image, ImageDraw

im_size = 1600

im1 = Image.new ('RGB', (im_size, im_size), (255, 255, 255))
draw1 = ImageDraw.Draw (im1)
point1 = ((-16000, -16000), (16000, 16000))
draw1.line (point1, fill = (0, 255, 0), width = 2)
im1.save ("./im1.png", "PNG", optimize = True)

im2 = Image.new ('RGB', (im_size, im_size), (255, 255, 255))
draw2 = ImageDraw.Draw (im2)
point2 = ((-16400, -16400), (16400, 16400))
draw2.line (point2, fill = (0, 255, 0), width = 2)
im2.save ("./im2.png", "PNG", optimize = True)
```

Python 3.8.2, Pillow 7.1.2 on Windows 10

Result: 
![im1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33727311/85308817-4b793800-b4e4-11ea-8385-90377caf5a1c.png)
![im2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33727311/85308824-4f0cbf00-b4e4-11ea-89d1-b9eb2525a9ae.png)

Seems something strange happens if the coordinate difference in either dimension goes beyond 32768. 

Not adding `width = 2` would be fine. 

I hope this will get fixed. My work involves mass auto-generated coordinates, and managing them within a bounded region without changing their appearance on the image seems too difficult a task.

items.title: Unable to draw a unicode character with combination characters
items.body:
### What did you do?
Draw a char with combination characters `a\u0308\u0325` using [HanaMin](http://fonts.jp/hanazono/). (See code below)

### What did you expect to happen?
The output should be ![圖片](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/531417/84581688-88736980-ae16-11ea-964b-3b5f28062991.png).

### What actually happened?
The output is ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/531417/84581671-611c9c80-ae16-11ea-9942-1e6d48eb62b2.png).

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: Windows 7 SP1
* Python: 3.8.1
* Pillow: 7.1.2

```python
from PIL import Image, ImageDraw, ImageFont

text = "a\u0308\u0325"
font = "HanaMinA.ttf"

img = Image.new('RGBA', (240, 80))
draw = ImageDraw.Draw(img)
fnt = ImageFont.truetype(font, 80)
dx, dy = fnt.getoffset(text)
draw.text((-dx, -dy), text, font=fnt, fill="#000")
img.save("image.png")
```

items.title: Unable to draw a unicode character with a variation selector

### What did you do?
Draw a char with a variation selector `\u51DE\U000E010B` using [HanaMin](http://fonts.jp/hanazono/). (See code below)

### What did you expect to happen?
The output should be ![圖片](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/531417/84581543-e30bc600-ae14-11ea-88c6-9a3379949624.png).

### What actually happened?
The output is ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/531417/84581562-06cf0c00-ae15-11ea-86cf-92f317de794e.png).

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: Windows 7 SP1
* Python: 3.8.1
* Pillow: 7.1.2

```python
from PIL import Image, ImageDraw, ImageFont

text = "\u51DE\U000E010B"
font = "HanaMinA.ttf"

img = Image.new('RGBA', (160, 80))
draw = ImageDraw.Draw(img)
fnt = ImageFont.truetype(font, 80)
dx, dy = fnt.getoffset(text)
draw.text((-dx, -dy), text, font=fnt, fill="#000")
img.save("image.png")
```

items.title: JPEG binary data changed after 5.3.0 on Windows (not on Linux)
items.body:
### What did you do?
Output a JPEG (converted from a PNG)

### What did you expect to happen?
I upgraded from Pillow 5.2.0 to 7.1.2 on Windows and Linux. I expected the binary JPEG data to remain the same. It did for Linux, but on Windows, the binary JPEG data changed (visually, the images look the same, but the RGB values have changed slightly too).

I did a little digging, and starting with build 5.3.0, on Windows, Pillow outputs data that is different from Linux, and different from previous releases.

### What actually happened?
See above.

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: Windows 10 & Ubuntu 18.04
* Python: 3.6.8 Windows, 3.6.9 Linux
* Pillow: 7.1.2 (all Pillow versions installed using pip)


Code:

```python
    import PIL
    from PIL import Image
    import numpy as np
    from scipy import misc as spm

    # image_data = Image.open(input_path)
    # np.save("npyout_{}.npy".format(PIL.__version__), image_data)
    # img = Image.fromarray(image_data)
    img = Image.open(input_path)
    out_path = "out_{}.jpg".format(PIL.__version__)
    img.save(out_path, format='JPEG', quality=95)
```

items.body:
### What did you do?
Converted a RAW file to PNG using RawTherapy 5.8.

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?
* OS:  Ubuntu 20.04

items.body:
<!--
Thank you for reporting an issue.

Follow these guidelines to ensure your issue is handled properly.

If you have a ...

1.  General question: consider asking the question on Stack Overflow
    with the python-imaging-library tag:

    * https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/python-imaging-library

    Do not ask a question in both places.

    If you think you have found a bug or have an unexplained exception
    then file a bug report here.

2.  Bug report: include a self-contained, copy-pastable example that
    generates the issue if possible. Be concise with code posted.
    Guidelines on how to provide a good bug report:

    * https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve

    Bug reports which follow these guidelines are easier to diagnose,
    and are often handled much more quickly.

3.  Feature request: do a quick search of existing issues
    to make sure this has not been asked before.

We know asking good questions takes effort, and we appreciate your time.
Thank you.
-->

### What did you do?
I drew two polygons, each specified by only two vertices that are both on a vertical or horizontal line.

### What did you expect to happen?
Expected to get a one pixel wide vertical and a one pixel wide horizontal line.

### What actually happened?
The vertical line shows but not the horizontal one.

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: Ubuntu 18.04.4
* Python: 3.7.6
* Pillow: 7.1.1

<!--
Please include **code** that reproduces the issue and whenever possible, an **image** that demonstrates the issue. Please upload images to GitHub, not to third-party file hosting sites. If necessary, add the image to a zip or tar archive.

The best reproductions are self-contained scripts with minimal dependencies. If you are using a framework such as Plone, Django, or Buildout, try to replicate the issue just using Pillow.
-->

```python
import numpy as np
from PIL import Image, ImageDraw
img = Image.new("L", size=(2,2), color=0)
ImageDraw.Draw(img).polygon([(0,0),(0,1)], outline=1, fill=1)
np.array(img)
```

gives

```python
array([[1, 0],
       [1, 0]], dtype=uint8)
```
but 
```python
import numpy as np
from PIL import Image, ImageDraw
img = Image.new("L", size=(2,2), color=0)
ImageDraw.Draw(img).polygon([(0,0),(1,0)], outline=1, fill=1)
np.array(img)
```
results in 
```python
array([[0, 0],
       [0, 0]], dtype=uint8)
```

items.title: PIL convert('ycbcr') gives different result from formula
items.body:
<!--
Thank you for reporting an issue.

Follow these guidelines to ensure your issue is handled properly.

If you have a ...

1.  General question: consider asking the question on Stack Overflow
    with the python-imaging-library tag:

    * https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/python-imaging-library

    Do not ask a question in both places.

    If you think you have found a bug or have an unexplained exception
    then file a bug report here.

2.  Bug report: include a self-contained, copy-pastable example that
    generates the issue if possible. Be concise with code posted.
    Guidelines on how to provide a good bug report:

    * https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve

    Bug reports which follow these guidelines are easier to diagnose,
    and are often handled much more quickly.

3.  Feature request: do a quick search of existing issues
    to make sure this has not been asked before.

We know asking good questions takes effort, and we appreciate your time.
Thank you.
-->

### What did you do?
compare PIL convert('ycbcr') function with formula listed on wikipedia
### What did you expect to happen?
they should have the same result
### What actually happened?
they have different result
### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: Windows 10
* Python: 3.7.4
* Pillow: 7.0.0

<!--
Please include **code** that reproduces the issue and whenever possible, an **image** that demonstrates the issue. Please upload images to GitHub, not to third-party file hosting sites. If necessary, add the image to a zip or tar archive.

The best reproductions are self-contained scripts with minimal dependencies. If you are using a framework such as Plone, Django, or Buildout, try to replicate the issue just using Pillow.
-->

```python
# The formula of RGB to YCbCr is from Wiki: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YCbCr
from PIL import Image
import numpy as np

# use PIL library
img = Image.open('any_image_you_have_in_hand.png').convert('RGB')
img, cb, cr = img.convert('YCbCr').split()
img = np.array(img).astype(np.float32) / 255.
print(img[:48,:48])

# use formula
def rgb_to_y(img_array):
    # formula is from wikipedia
    R,G,B = img_array[0], img_array[1], img_array[2]
    return 16. + (65.481 * R + 128.553 * G + 24.966 * B) / 255.

img2 = Image.open('any_image_you_have_in_hand.png').convert('RGB')
img2 = np.array(img2).transpose((2, 0, 1)).astype(np.float32) # c,h,w
img2 = rgb_to_y(img2) / 255.
print(img2[:48,:48])
```
different results will be generated...and I have no idea which one to use...

items.title: Release Pillow 7.2.0 on July 1, 2020
items.body:
* [x] Open a release ticket e.g. https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/issues/3154
* [x] Develop and prepare release in `master` branch.
* [x] Check [GitHub Actions](https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/actions),
      [Travis CI](https://travis-ci.org/github/python-pillow/Pillow) and
      [AppVeyor](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/python-pillow/Pillow) to confirm
      passing tests in `master` branch.
* [x] Check that all of the wheel builds [Pillow Wheel Builder](https://github.com/python-pillow/pillow-wheels) pass the tests in Travis CI.
* [x] In compliance with [PEP 440](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0440/), update version identifier in `src/PIL/_version.py`
* [x] Update `CHANGES.rst`.
* [x] Run pre-release check via `make release-test` in a freshly cloned repo.
* [x] Create branch and tag for release e.g.:
  ```bash
  git branch 5.2.x
  git tag 5.2.0
  git push --all
  git push --tags
  ```
* [x] Create source distributions e.g.:
  ```bash
  make sdist
  ```
* [x] Create [binary distributions](https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/blob/master/RELEASING.md#binary-distributions)
* [x] Upload all binaries and source distributions e.g. `twine upload dist/Pillow-5.2.0*`
* [x] Create a [new release on GitHub](https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/releases/new)
* [x] In compliance with [PEP 440](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0440/), increment and append `.dev0` to version identifier in `src/PIL/_version.py`

## Binary Distributions

### Windows
* [x] Contact `@cgohlke` for Windows binaries via release ticket e.g. https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/issues/1174.
* [x] Download and extract tarball from `@cgohlke` and `twine upload *`.

### Mac and Linux
* [x] Use the [Pillow Wheel Builder](https://github.com/python-pillow/pillow-wheels):
  ```bash
  git clone https://github.com/python-pillow/pillow-wheels
  cd pillow-wheels
  ./update-pillow-tag.sh [[release tag]]
  ```
* [x] Download distributions from the [Pillow Wheel Builder container](http://a365fff413fe338398b6-1c8a9b3114517dc5fe17b7c3f8c63a43.r19.cf2.rackcdn.com/).
  ```bash
  wget -m -A 'Pillow-<VERSION>-*' \
  http://a365fff413fe338398b6-1c8a9b3114517dc5fe17b7c3f8c63a43.r19.cf2.rackcdn.com
  ```

## Publicize Release

* [x] Announce release availability via [Twitter](https://twitter.com/pythonpillow) e.g. https://twitter.com/PythonPillow/status/1013789184354603010

## Documentation

* [x] Make sure the [default version for Read the Docs](https://pillow.readthedocs.io/en/stable/) is up-to-date with the release changes

items.title: ImageFont cant find _imagingft C module when CV2 is also imported
items.body:
<!--
Thank you for reporting an issue.

Follow these guidelines to ensure your issue is handled properly.

If you have a ...

1.  General question: consider asking the question on Stack Overflow
    with the python-imaging-library tag:

    * https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/python-imaging-library

    Do not ask a question in both places.

    If you think you have found a bug or have an unexplained exception
    then file a bug report here.

2.  Bug report: include a self-contained, copy-pastable example that
    generates the issue if possible. Be concise with code posted.
    Guidelines on how to provide a good bug report:

    * https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve

    Bug reports which follow these guidelines are easier to diagnose,
    and are often handled much more quickly.

3.  Feature request: do a quick search of existing issues
    to make sure this has not been asked before.

We know asking good questions takes effort, and we appreciate your time.
Thank you.
-->

### What did you do?
I have a workflow where some of the image processing is done in Pillow and some in OpenCV(4.2.0) ImageFont can't load fonts when cv2 is also imported. Issue does not happen when cv2 is imported after PIL, only when cv2 is imported before PIL

### What did you expect to happen?
ImageFont Loads the font.
### What actually happened?
```shell
----> 1 font = ImageFont.truetype('/usr/share/fonts/truetype/dejavu/DejaVuSansMono-Bold.ttf', size=28)

####/miniconda3/envs/image_env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/PIL/ImageFont.py in truetype(font, size, index, encoding, layout_engine)
    640
    641     try:
--> 642         return freetype(font)
    643     except OSError:
    644         if not isPath(font):

####/miniconda3/envs/image_env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/PIL/ImageFont.py in freetype(font)
    637
    638     def freetype(font):
--> 639         return FreeTypeFont(font, size, index, encoding, layout_engine)
    640
    641     try:

####/miniconda3/envs/image_env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/PIL/ImageFont.py in __init__(self, font, size, index, encoding, layout_engine)
    161         if layout_engine not in (LAYOUT_BASIC, LAYOUT_RAQM):
    162             layout_engine = LAYOUT_BASIC
--> 163             if core.HAVE_RAQM:
    164                 layout_engine = LAYOUT_RAQM
    165         elif layout_engine == LAYOUT_RAQM and not core.HAVE_RAQM:

####/miniconda3/envs/image_env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/PIL/ImageFont.py in __getattr__(self, id)
     41     # module placeholder
     42     def __getattr__(self, id):
---> 43         raise ImportError("The _imagingft C module is not installed")
     44
     45

ImportError: The _imagingft C module is not installed
```

I have confirmed and reinstalled the external libraries involved.
### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: Ubuntu 16.04
* Python: 3.6.0
* Pillow: 7.0.0.post3

<!--
Please include **code** that reproduces the issue and whenever possible, an **image** that demonstrates the issue. Please upload images to GitHub, not to third-party file hosting sites. If necessary, add the image to a zip or tar archive.

The best reproductions are self-contained scripts with minimal dependencies. If you are using a framework such as Plone, Django, or Buildout, try to replicate the issue just using Pillow.
-->

```python
>>> import cv2
>>> from PIL import Image, ImageFilter, ImageDraw, ImageFont
>>> font = ImageFont.truetype('/usr/share/fonts/truetype/dejavu/DejaVuSansMono-Bold.ttf', size=28)
```


* Pillow: 6.2.2

rather than
_pip3 install pyproj_
happened to him in the X-Plane forum, so I attempted to reproduce it and I did.

We know asking good questions takes effort, and we appreciate your time.
Thank you.

items.title: Division by zero when creating a thumbnail

labels.name: Bug

items.body:
Hi,
Sorry if this as already been reported, but when trying to create a thumbnail (80, 80) from an image (550, 5)  I get a divide by zero 

```python
Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "C:\Python38\lib\site-packages\PIL\Image.py", line 2272, in round_aspect
    return max(min(math.floor(number), math.ceil(number), key=key), 1)
  File "C:\Python38\lib\site-packages\PIL\Image.py", line 2279, in <lambda>
    y = round_aspect(x / aspect, key=lambda n: abs(aspect - x / n))
ZeroDivisionError: division by zero
```
It looks like the key (n) can be be zero so perhaps the code needs to test for it?

Tim

items.body:
<!--
Thank you for reporting an issue.

Follow these guidelines to ensure your issue is handled properly.

If you have a ...

1.  General question: consider asking the question on Stack Overflow
    with the python-imaging-library tag:

    * https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/python-imaging-library

    Do not ask a question in both places.

    If you think you have found a bug or have an unexplained exception
    then file a bug report here.

2.  Bug report: include a self-contained, copy-pastable example that
    generates the issue if possible. Be concise with code posted.
    Guidelines on how to provide a good bug report:

    * https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve

    Bug reports which follow these guidelines are easier to diagnose,
    and are often handled much more quickly.

3.  Feature request: do a quick search of existing issues
    to make sure this has not been asked before.

We know asking good questions takes effort, and we appreciate your time.
Thank you.
-->

### What did you do?
I'm trying to read RGBA image from Windows clipboard, and convert the image to RGB format with a white background. The RGBA image was copyed from chrome browser.  

### What did you expect to happen?
The returned image from ```ImageGrab.grabclipboard()``` should be in RGBA mode.  

### What actually happened?
The returned image from ```ImageGrab.grabclipboard()``` is already in RGB mode, with black background.  

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: Windows 10
* Python: 3.6.8
* Pillow: 7.0.0

<!--
Please include **code** that reproduces the issue and whenever possible, an **image** that demonstrates the issue. Please upload images to GitHub, not to third-party file hosting sites. If necessary, add the image to a zip or tar archive.

The best reproductions are self-contained scripts with minimal dependencies. If you are using a framework such as Plone, Django, or Buildout, try to replicate the issue just using Pillow.
-->

```python
new_image = ImageGrab.grabclipboard()
new_image_converted = Image.new("RGB", new_image.size, (255, 255, 255))
new_image_converted.paste(new_image)
```

items.title: is_animated should be defined for all images
items.body:
### What did you do?

I have a user with a photo. I want to check if the photo is animated. I ran the code:
```python
from PIL import Image

if (Image.open(user.photo.file).is_animated):
````

### What did you expect to happen?

I expect `is_animated` to be defined for all images.
https://stackoverflow.com/a/50808096/1412564
https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/pull/1319

### What actually happened?
If the image if not a GIF, I got an exception:

'JpegImageFile' object has no attribute 'is_animated'

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: Ubuntu 18.04
* Python: 3.6
* Pillow: 7.1.2

items.title: Image.fromarray() cannot handle 1-D arrays
items.body:
Running Pillow ~~7.0.0~~ (EDIT: now 7.1.2) on Python 3.7.6 on Windows 10 x64

I am converting a float32 grayscale array to Pillow so that I can use some of the image operations. This is not strictly an actual image and I want to preserve the order of the grayscale values. Having to reshape the array to use these operations doesn't seem intended. The grayscale values are stored in index 3 of the dataset. When I try to load the array into the Pillow Image class, it throws an error because `__array_interface__['shape'][1]` is missing on a 1-D array. This is the Numpy intended behavior (see https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.ndarray.shape.html). There is no check for this in `Image.fromarray()`.

Relevant code:
```python
rows = np.loadtxt (f, dtype = int, max_rows = 1)
columns = np.loadtxt (f, dtype = int, max_rows = 1)
inputPoints = np.loadtxt (f, delimiter=' ', max_rows = (rows * columns))
testArray = 255 * inputPoints[:,3]
print (testArray.__array_interface__)
print (len (testArray.__array_interface__['shape']))
grayImage = Image.fromarray (testArray, mode = 'L')
```

Output:

```python
{'data': (2080565403600, False), 'strides': None, 'descr': [('', '<f8')], 'typestr': '<f8', 'shape': (29118,), 'version': 3}
1
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".\test.py", line 333, in <module>
    grayImage = Image.fromarray (testArray, mode = 'L')
  File "D:\ProgramData\Anaconda3\envs\vtkvista37env\lib\site-packages\PIL\Image.py", line 2694, in fromarray
    size = shape[1], shape[0]
IndexError: tuple index out of range
```

Context in Image.py:

```python
    arr = obj.__array_interface__
    shape = arr["shape"]
    ndim = len(shape)
    strides = arr.get("strides", None)

    [some code for mode and dimensions]

    size = shape[1], shape[0]
```

I might suggest something like:

```python
    size = 1 if ndim == 1 else shape[1],  shape[0]
```

Thank you!

items.title: JPEGs recognised as MPOs
items.body: Unsure why issue #1198 was closed as it is still a bug, learned this the hard way when a user tried to upload a JPEG and Pillow mistook it for a MPO and exploded.

items.title: ImageDraw.Draw.fontmode = '1' not working in 7.0.0
items.body:
### What did you do?

Updated my Pillow dependency from 6.x to 7.x.

### What did you expect to happen?

For the anti-anti-aliasing workaround to still be working. 

```
txt_mask_draw = ImageDraw.Draw(txt_mask, mode="RGB")
txt_mask_draw.fontmode = "1"
```
By setting `fontmode = "1"`, text would be rendered only with the color given.

### What actually happened?

The font is anti-aliased which means that it is not all the same color.

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: Archlinux
* Python: 3.8
* Pillow: 7.1

I don't have a repro yet, my usecase is tangled in some other code, but it clearly broke with the version change because I can toggle it by switching between `pillow==6.0.0` and `pillow==7.1.0` with `pip`.

Pillow 7.1.0
![alias](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5399488/80870495-c7899900-8c74-11ea-819a-841ef5aabed7.png)

Pillow 6.0.0
![out_0](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5399488/80870498-cb1d2000-8c74-11ea-8490-741bac4bf2d8.png)

items.body:

items.title: exif[11] = "Pillow test" does not pass the tests
items.body:
I found a couple of errors in `Tests/test_imagefile.py`.
Text assignments like `exif[11] = "Pillow test" ` were not properly tested.

When fixing the test (PR #4594), it does not pass.

This is consistent with my trials on separate code.

items.title: png image processing bug
items.body:
### What did you do?
I need to handle this image with Pillow
[001_R2.zip](https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/files/4535520/001_R2.zip)


### What actually happened?
```PIL.UnidentifiedImageError: cannot identify image file '001_R2.png'```

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: Any (checked at windows/linux)
* Python: Any (checked 3.6-3.9)
* Pillow: I checked at 6.*, 7.* Maybe any


```python
from PIL import Image

Image.open('001_R2.png')   # exception
```

I can fix this by simply doing:

convert 001_R2.png 001_R2_fixed.png

`file` utility shows file identity

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1452243/80311048-2b7c0f80-87e6-11ea-8e79-81bb1062aefd.png)

Problem persists on all PCs on which i could check it.
Thanks

items.title: Cropping a TiffImageFile removes other images in stack
items.body:
I'm trying to crop a imageJ hyperstack along the x,y axis. Calling .crop on the Image file converts it into a PIL.Image.Image, and I can't see a way to re-create an image stack without saving a new image to a file (+ using append_images=[...]).

I this an implementation issue or am I looking at this issue from the wrong perspective?

items.title: Bug with line joints

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Any unexpected behavior, until confirmed feature.

items.body:
### What did you do?

When I use the `joint='curve'` attribute on the line method with a sequence of numeric value, I get an error.

### What did you expect to happen?

[The documentation say](https://pillow.readthedocs.io/en/stable/reference/ImageDraw.html#PIL.ImageDraw.PIL.ImageDraw.ImageDraw.line) that you can pass *Sequence of either 2-tuples or numeric values*.

So, this should work:
```pycon
>>> from PIL import Image, ImageDraw
>>> im = Image.new('RGB', (800, 600))
>>> draw = ImageDraw.Draw(im)
>>> draw.line((400, 200, 300, 280, 100, 280), 0, 50, joint='curve')
```


### What actually happened?

 *Sequence of 2-tuples*  and `joint='curve'` works fine :

```pycon
>>> draw.line(((400, 200), (300, 280), (100, 280)), 0, 50, joint='curve')
```

*Sequence of numeric values*, but no `joint='curve'` works fine : 

```pycon
>>> draw.line((400,200,300,280,100,280), 0, 50)
```

*Sequence of numeric values*   and `joint='curve'` doesn't work :
```pycon
>>> draw.line((400,200,300,280,100,280), 0, 50, joint='curve')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/leon/virtualenvs/ogn/lib/python3.5/site-packages/PIL/ImageDraw.py", line 165, in line
    for start, end in ((xy[i-1], point), (point, xy[i+1]))
  File "/home/leon/virtualenvs/ogn/lib/python3.5/site-packages/PIL/ImageDraw.py", line 165, in <listcomp>
    for start, end in ((xy[i-1], point), (point, xy[i+1]))
TypeError: 'int' object is not subscriptable
```

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: Debian Linux
* Python: 3.5.3
* Pillow: '5.4.1'

items.title: PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile images can't be saved as GIFs in 7.1.1
items.body:
### What did you do?

Asset Download:
```python
from urllib.request import urlopen
from PIL import Image

def download_and_save(url, name):
    im = Image.open(urlopen(url))
    im = im.resize((500, 293)).crop((0, 0, 500, 290))
    im.save(f'{name}.png')
    im.save(f'{name}.jpg')

download_and_save('https://www.nicepng.com/png/detail/50-503681_shaq-face-png-moniece-slaughter.png', 'shaq')
download_and_save('https://hips.hearstapps.com/hmg-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/images/close-up-of-cat-wearing-sunglasses-while-sitting-royalty-free-image-1571755145.jpg', 'cat')
```

JPG works:
```python
shaq = Image.open('shaq.jpg')
cat = Image.open('cat.jpg')
type(shaq)
# PIL.JpegImagePlugin.JpegImageFile

shaq.save(
    'shaq_cat_jpg.gif',
    save_all=True,
    append_images=[cat],
    duration=200,
    loop=0
)
```

PNG doesn't work:
```python
shaq = Image.open('shaq.png')
cat = Image.open('cat.png')
type(shaq)
# PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile

shaq.save(
    'shaq_cat_png.gif',
    save_all=True,
    append_images=[cat],
    duration=200,
    loop=0
)
```

### What did you expect to happen?

Both JPG and PNG code should run.

### What actually happened?

PNG code errors out with `ValueError: read of closed file`

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: macOS
* Python: 3.7
* Pillow: 7.1.1 (works on 7.0.0)

###

Both the PNG and JPG code run on 6.0.0 and 7.0.0, though!

items.title: loop=1 actually loops twice?
items.body:
### What did you do?

```python
from PIL import Image

r = Image.new('RGB', (500, 500), (255, 0, 0))
g = Image.new('RGB', (500, 500), (0, 255, 0))
b = Image.new('RGB', (500, 500), (0, 0, 255))

frames = [r, g, b]

frames[0].save(
    'rgb.gif',
    save_all=True,
    append_images=frames[1:],
    duration=500, # TURNED WAY UP TO BE CAREFUL
    loop=1
)
```

### What did you expect to happen?

Play through once.

### What actually happened?

Plays twice, loops once. Hard to know what argument to use because, as documented, `loop=0` makes it loop infinitely.

![rgb](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2367311/80044064-6114b600-84d1-11ea-9012-5f55001af591.gif)

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: macOS
* Python: 3.7
* Pillow: 7.0.0 (seems PNG gifs are broken in 7.1.0 and 7.1.1?)


items.title: Mac wheel includes ad-hoc signed libxcb
items.body:
### What did you do?

I have a Python binary that is built using PyInstaller, and is packaged/signed for macOS. Binaries began failing to execute when Pillow was updated to 7.1.1.

`libxcb.1.dylib` seems to be getting pulled into the package by PyInstaller. This binary includes an ad-hoc signature, and when `codesign` is run on the app bundle, this signature is not overwritten.

This can be verified as follows:

```bash
$ python3 -m venv venv
$ . venv/bin/activate
$ pip install pillow==7.1.1
$ codesign -dvvvv venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/PIL/.dylibs/libxcb.1.dylib
```

### What did you expect to happen?

All of the other dylibs shipped with the Pillow binary packages are unsigned, and this tends to be the case for most wheels I've encountered. Also, according to the [7.1.0 release notes](https://pillow.readthedocs.io/en/stable/releasenotes/7.1.0.html#x11-imagegrab-grab), XCB support isn't included in macOS wheels by default, so I'm not sure whether libxcb being included is intentional or not.

### What actually happened?

An ad-hoc signed libxcb was included in the packaged wheels.

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: macOS 10.14 Mojave
* Python: 3.6
* Pillow: 7.1.1

items.title: How to Reverse Pillow Rotate Translation when expand set to True, or not cropping when expand set to False
items.body:
Please see investigation here:-

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/61128407/reversing-the-translation-of-the-pillow-image-library-rotation

### What did you do?
I rotated two images on a still background, and made them into a still video.

### What did you expect to happen?
I was expecting the two images to be rotated, and their centre points to be still in the same location after rotation.

### What actually happened?
They did rotate, however, the centre points of the two rotated images also moved !?
This happens when expand is set to True.  However, when expand is set to False, it crops the rotated images corners symmetrically, as can be seen in the google drive links shared.

Is there a way I can rotate an image without the centre point moving, and without the corners being cropped off the other corners?  Or is there a way to reverse the translation that comes about when expand=True, as a post process translation ?  

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS:  Windows 10
* Python: 3.7
* PIL: 6.1.0

There is code and video examples in the Stackoverflow link at the top.  I am not sure if this is a bug or a question !?

items.title: Cannot compress tiff file to group4
items.body:
<!--
Thank you for reporting an issue.

Follow these guidelines to ensure your issue is handled properly.

If you have a ...

1.  General question: consider asking the question on Stack Overflow
    with the python-imaging-library tag:

    * https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/python-imaging-library

    Do not ask a question in both places.

    If you think you have found a bug or have an unexplained exception
    then file a bug report here.

2.  Bug report: include a self-contained, copy-pastable example that
    generates the issue if possible. Be concise with code posted.
    Guidelines on how to provide a good bug report:

    * https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve

    Bug reports which follow these guidelines are easier to diagnose,
    and are often handled much more quickly.

3.  Feature request: do a quick search of existing issues
    to make sure this has not been asked before.

We know asking good questions takes effort, and we appreciate your time.
Thank you.
-->

### What did you do?
I want to compress tiff file to group4.

### What did you expect to happen?
Not error.

### What actually happened?
It errored.

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: Linux
* Python: 3.7 
* Pillow: 7.1.1

<!--
Please include **code** that reproduces the issue and whenever possible, an **image** that demonstrates the issue. Please upload images to GitHub, not to third-party file hosting sites. If necessary, add the image to a zip or tar archive.

The best reproductions are self-contained scripts with minimal dependencies. If you are using a framework such as Plone, Django, or Buildout, try to replicate the issue just using Pillow.
-->

Part1
```python
from pdf2image import convert_from_bytes

def main():
    input_path = "./data/hogehoge.pdf"
    output_path = "./data/hogehoge.tif"
    with open(input_path, "rb") as f:
        images = convert_from_bytes(
            pdf_file=f.read(),
            grayscale=True)
    images[0].save(
        output_path,
        format='TIFF',
        dpi=(400, 400),
        compression="group4",
        save_all=True,
        append_images=images[1:])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

The error message is:
```python
  File "./main.py", line 16, in main
    append_images=images[1:])
  File "~/lib/python3.7/site-packages/PIL/Image.py", line 2134, in save
    save_handler(self, fp, filename)
  File "~/lib/python3.7/site-packages/PIL/TiffImagePlugin.py", line 1900, in _save_all
    _save(ims, tf, filename)
  File "~/lib/python3.7/site-packages/PIL/TiffImagePlugin.py", line 1626, in _save
    raise OSError("encoder error %d when writing image file" % s)
  OSError: encoder error -2 when writing image file
```

Part2
```python
from pdf2image import convert_from_bytes
from PIL.TiffImagePlugin import ImageFileDirectory_v2, TiffTags

def main():
    input_path = "./data/hogehoge.pdf"
    output_path = "./data/hogehoge.tif"
    with open(input_path, "rb") as f:
        images = convert_from_bytes(
            pdf_file=f.read(),
            grayscale=True)
    ifd = ImageFileDirectory_v2()
    ifd[259] = "group4"
    ifd.tagtype[259] = TiffTags.SHORT
    images[0].save(
        output_path,
        format='TIFF',
        tiffinfo=ifd,
        dpi=(400, 400),
        compression="group4",
        save_all=True,
        append_images=images[1:])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

Not errored but check tiffinfo is below.
Compression Scheme is not group 4.
```console
$ tiffinfo hogehoge.tif
TIFF Directory at offset 0x2c3fdc8 (46398920)
  Image Width: 1653 Image Length: 2339
  Resolution: 400, 400 pixels/inch
  Bits/Sample: 8
  Compression Scheme: None
  Photometric Interpretation: min-is-black
  Rows/Strip: 2339
  Planar Configuration: single image plane
...
```

items.title: EXIF orientation is not updated when saving rotated/transposed image
items.body:
### What did you do?
Saved a transposed image in PNG format

### What did you expect to happen?
EXIF orientation to be updated accordingly

### What actually happened?
EXIF orientation information in the saved image is incorrect

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?
* OS: Ubuntu 18.04 LTS 
* Python: 3.8.0
* Pillow: 7.1.0

```python
from PIL import Image, __version__

EXIF_ORIENTATION = 0x0112
ROTATION = {3: Image.ROTATE_180, 6: Image.ROTATE_270, 8: Image.ROTATE_90}


def convert(input_filename, output_filename, image_format="PNG"):
    img = Image.open(input_filename)
    exif = img._getexif()
    if exif is not None:
        if EXIF_ORIENTATION in exif.keys():
            code = exif[EXIF_ORIENTATION]
            angle = ROTATION.get(code, None)
            print(f"filename: {input_filename};  EXIF rotation code: {code}")
            if angle is not None:
                img = img.transpose(angle)
    img.save(output_filename, format=image_format)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    print(f"PIL version: {__version__}")

    convert("A.JPG", "B.PNG")
    convert("B.PNG", "C.PNG")
```

Code output:
```bash
PIL version: 7.1.0
filename: A.JPG;  EXIF rotation code: 8
filename: B.PNG;  EXIF rotation code: 8
```
Expected output
```bash
PIL version: 7.1.0
filename: A.JPG;  EXIF rotation code: 8
filename: B.PNG;  EXIF rotation code: 1
```
Repository including code and test image:
[https://github.com/RomanKosobrodov/test-pillow-rotation](https://github.com/RomanKosobrodov/test-pillow-rotation)

items.title: ImageFont documentation does not match with current code
items.body:
### What did you do?

Read the docs on 
https://pillow.readthedocs.io/en/stable/reference/ImageFont.html#PIL.ImageFont.ImageFont
and then the code by following the link provided there, to
https://pillow.readthedocs.io/en/stable/_modules/PIL/ImageFont.html#load

### What did you expect to happen?

Since the documentation claims that only an IOError is raised, I expected to see the code raising an IOError.

### What actually happened?

The code shows an OSError being raised, as a result of this commit: https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/commit/538d9e2e5d252bea23e12da08495945d776aed78#diff-0b53b789652f38dc633674dd3671e636L82

items.title: Provide a C API independent of CPython for the core functionality
items.body:
As part of the recently started [TensorFlow for Java](https://github.com/tensorflow/java) project, we are striving to make TensorFlow fully usable from Java, without depending on CPython. For this purpose, TensorFlow itself offers a supported and stable C API that we can use independently from CPython. However, the Python API of TensorFlow known as Keras uses Pillow internally to process images, and given issues like #4445, we would also need to use Pillow from Java to obtain reproducible results, ideally without going through CPython. (Pillow can be called very easily from Java by using JavaCPP, so that part is not an issue, see https://github.com/bytedeco/javacpp-presets.)

I believe that most of the code of Pillow written in C could be separated without too much trouble into modules that do not depend on CPython, but before diving into the implementation details, we would like to know if this is something the developers of Pillow would be interested in maintaining, and if so, how we could assist you in the process. Thank you for your consideration!

/cc @karllessard

items.title: Support for 3D Data
items.body:
Enabling Pillow to deal with 3D data would enable a broader use case. 
Especially in the medical domain data often is 3D and being able to deal with it potentially also with torchvision and Pillow would be really nice.

Of course, slice-wise processing of 3D volumes is also possible, however, in certain cases, augmentations need to be applied to the whole volume.

I would be really interested to hear if support for 3D data is planned at some point.

items.title: PIL failed to extract EXIF while MacOS Preview App can
items.body:
### What did you do?
Hi, I'm trying to extract EXIF from the bellow PNG image, mainly to rotate it correctly based on the orientation information inside the EXIF tags.

![test](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26834698/78507395-ebf37200-77a9-11ea-951d-e60d3560e8ba.png)

with this simple script:

```python
import PIL

print(PIL.__version__)
from PIL import Image

image = 'test.png'
exif_info = Image.open(image).getexif()
print(exif_info)
```

but PIL failed to extract any EXIF information out of it. I can confirm that the EXIF information is there and can be detected via Preview app on MacOS:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26834698/78507416-0fb6b800-77aa-11ea-8670-d80f9d914457.png)

As you can see, it said: **Orientation: 8 (Rotated 90° CW)**

### What did you expect to happen?
`getexif()` return the EXIF information for the image, at least contain the orientation like MacOS Preview did.

Noted that some month ago I ran the same exact code and everything work fine, maybe somehow `getexif()` was broken in newer version of Pillow. I have tried to revert back to `6.0.0` but it does not solve the problem.

Also I have noticed that `getexif()` will almost fail with any file was rotated by Quick Look tool from MacOS

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26834698/78507583-1134b000-77ab-11ea-8b1b-d83fe7508846.png)


### What actually happened?
`getexif()` return an empty `dict` and failed to extract any EXIF

Output:
```bash
7.1.1
{}
```

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: MacOS Mojave 10.14.5
* Python: Python 3.7.6
* Pillow: 7.1.1

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Any unexpected behavior, until confirmed feature.

items.body:
<!--
Thank you for reporting an issue.

Follow these guidelines to ensure your issue is handled properly.

If you have a ...

1.  General question: consider asking the question on Stack Overflow
    with the python-imaging-library tag:

    * https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/python-imaging-library

    Do not ask a question in both places.

    If you think you have found a bug or have an unexplained exception
    then file a bug report here.

2.  Bug report: include a self-contained, copy-pastable example that
    generates the issue if possible. Be concise with code posted.
    Guidelines on how to provide a good bug report:

    * https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve

    Bug reports which follow these guidelines are easier to diagnose,
    and are often handled much more quickly.

3.  Feature request: do a quick search of existing issues
    to make sure this has not been asked before.

We know asking good questions takes effort, and we appreciate your time.
Thank you.
-->

### What did you do?

Following on from #4509 after the 7.1.0 release, we have a new issue that cropped up opening a png from scikit-image.

### What did you expect to happen?

Not error.

### What actually happened?

It errored.

### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: Linux
* Python: 3.8.2
* Pillow: 7.1.0

<!--
Please include **code** that reproduces the issue and whenever possible, an **image** that demonstrates the issue. Please upload images to GitHub, not to third-party file hosting sites. If necessary, add the image to a zip or tar archive.

The best reproductions are self-contained scripts with minimal dependencies. If you are using a framework such as Plone, Django, or Buildout, try to replicate the issue just using Pillow.
-->
The code should just be loading a scikit-image PNG data:

```python
from skimage import data
original = data.camera().astype('float')
```
The error message is:
```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/opt/miniconda/envs/sunpy/lib/python3.8/site-packages/skimage/data/__init__.py", line 109, in camera
    return _load("camera.png")
```

Since this is scikit image loading one of their PNGs, I wonder if it's actually a bug there.

items.title: RGBA Image.resize is lossy because of RGBa conversion
items.body: ### What did you do? I have a RGB-D image (RGB plus depth channel). I load it as a RGBA image in PIL for image processing. However after the Image.resize operation, the values in the RGB channels that correspond to `A==0` are set to zero. ### What did you expect to happen? I would expect the RGB values to stay the same, and only the size of the image to change. ### What actually happened? Any pixels where the alpha channel was zero, became zero in all channels. Here's an example visualization. The code to reproduce it is below. ### Why did this happen? It appears this is because the Image.resize function calls self.convert('RGBa') and after resizing the image then converts back to RGBA. RGBa is "true color with premultiplied alpha" while RGBA is "true color with transparency mask" [1](https://pillow.readthedocs.io/en/4.0.x/handbook/concepts.html#modes). It appears to be a lossy operation. ### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions? * OS: MacOSX 10.14 * Python: 3.7 * Pillow: 6.2.1 ### MCVE I'm using this example image as a stand in for my RGB image. ![glass.png](https://i.stack.imgur.com/fE2Su.png) The depth channel is stored as a seperate png image, but for this MCVE I've used a numpy array ```python from PIL import Image import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import numpy as np img_path = 'glass.png' img = Image.open(img_path).convert('RGB') # Load depth from file #depth_path = 'glass_d.png' #depth = Image.open(depth_path).convert('L') # Toy depth for code example depth_arr = np.zeros((180,180)) depth_arr[50:150, 50:100] = 255 depth = Image.fromarray(depth_arr).convert('L') # Add the depth as alpha channel img.putalpha(depth) # Make a copy and resize to demonstrate problem img_resize = img.copy() img_resize = img_resize.resize((250, 250), Image.NEAREST) # Visualization of result plt.figure() plt.subplot('221') plt.imshow(img) plt.title('Image before resize') plt.subplot('222') plt.imshow(np.array(img)[:, :, :3]) plt.title('RGB channels before resize') plt.subplot('223') plt.imshow(img_resize) plt.title('Image after resize') plt.subplot('224') plt.imshow(np.array(img_resize)[:, :, :3]) plt.title('RGB channels after resize') plt.show() ```

My library BentoML is using imageio and Pillow in its tests, and with the latest release of Pillow 7.1.0 half an hour ago, I noticed some existing tests are breaking. https://github.com/bentoml/BentoML https://travis-ci.org/github/bentoml/BentoML/jobs/669765333?utm_medium=notification&utm_source=github_status ### What did you expect to happen? `imageio.imread('./image.png')` should work ### What actually happened? ``` AttributeError: 'PngImageFile' object has no attribute '_PngImageFile__frame' ``` ### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions? * OS: mac os * Python: 3.75 * Pillow: 7.1.0 * imageio: 2.8.0 ```python from imageio import imread imread('./test.png') ``` It seems related to https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/pull/4243

items.title: GHA: Add retry mechanism

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Any unexpected behavior, until confirmed feature.

items.body:
The "Install Linux dependencies" step of test.yml is failing intermittently with timeouts on GitHub Actions.

```
Reading package lists...
E: Failed to fetch http://azure.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/pool/main/b/blt/tk8.6-blt2.5_2.5.3+dfsg-4_amd64.deb  Could not connect to azure.archive.ubuntu.com:80 (52.177.174.250), connection timed out
```

It's possible to restart failures, but unlike Travis CI (which allows you to restart single jobs) and AppVeyor (which allows you to restart failed jobs), you can only re-run all the jobs on GHA.

At least it only re-runs the jobs in a single workflow, but it's still more than needed, and you may get a timeout in another job.

Let's add some sort of retry mechanism. Perhaps something similar to `travis_retry`

* https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/common-build-problems/#travis_retry
* https://stackoverflow.com/q/59356518/724176

items.title: Does PIL provide an implementation of KCF (Kernel Correlation Filter) tracking?
items.body:
Hi guys,
I found it seemed Pillow didn't provide a encapsulated function of  KCF (Kernel Correlation Filter) tracking, do you?
Your idea and answer will be appreciated!

items.title: RTL Direction issue

labels.name: Installation
labels.description: Usually a problem with …

items.body:
### What did you do?
I'm trying to put an RTL(Right to left direction) text(Arabic) on an image
### What did you expect to happen?
being able to set the direction of the text
### What actually happened?
I got an error saying setting text direction, language or font features is not supported without libraqm
### What are your OS, Python and Pillow versions?

* OS: Windows (Running pycharm virtual python)
* Python: 3.6
* Pillow: PIL 7.0.0

<!--
Please include **code** that reproduces the issue and whenever possible, an **image** that demonstrates the issue. Please upload images to GitHub, not to third-party file hosting sites. If necessary, add the image to a zip or tar archive.

The best reproductions are self-contained scripts with minimal dependencies. If you are using a framework such as Plone, Django, or Buildout, try to replicate the issue just using Pillow.
-->

```python
import PIL
import arabic_reshaper
from PIL import Image, ImageDraw, ImageFont
from bidi.algorithm import get_display

    image = Image.open('main.jpeg')

    draw = ImageDraw.Draw(image)

    font = ImageFont.truetype('din-next-lt-w23-medium.ttf', size=60)

    text_to_be_reshaped = 'محمد'
    reshaped_text = arabic_reshaper.reshape(text_to_be_reshaped)
    bidi_text = get_display(reshaped_text)
    print(bidi_text.__sizeof__() + font.size)
    print(type(bidi_text))
    (x, y) = (1050, 463)
    color = 'rgb(255, 255, 255)'  # white color
    draw.text((x, y), bidi_text, fill=color, font=font, direction="rtl")

    # draw the message on the background

    image.save('result.png')
```

items.title: Re-enable Zenodo for citable releases
items.body:
In https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/issues/1322 we enabled Zenodo to create DOIs for Pillow releases, so it can be citable. And it's worked! We have some [citations](https://zenodo.org/record/44297#.Xn-z5dP7QWo)!

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1324225/77833256-a1884a80-7144-11ea-9a91-71e0c904ebf7.png)

However, at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.596518, we can see Pillow 3.0.0 and 3.1.0, but nothing newer.

@aclark4life Please could you check the settings? I don't have permission.

For example, at https://zenodo.org/account/settings/github/repository/hugovk/Pillow I can see:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1324225/77833240-86b5d600-7144-11ea-8a7f-65b9ba279d11.png)

How does https://zenodo.org/account/settings/github/repository/python-pillow/Pillow look?

General guide: https://guides.github.com/activities/citable-code/

### What actually happened?
